claims.claim_text: A stack is a type of data structure that operates on the principle of Last In, First Out (LIFO). It stores data items with two main operations: push (adding an item) and pop (removing an item). This makes it useful for tasks where you need to keep track of things in the reverse order they were added.
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: The Principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO) is a rule for managing data structures called stacks. It means that the last item added to a stack is the first one to be removed, like items in a tray where you can only take from the top. This principle is crucial as it allows operations such as 'push' and 'pop'.
